questions.text: A 25-year-old woman who is known to have a cardiac murmur becomes pregnant. It is noted that the intensity of her murmur diminishes during her pregnancy. Which cardiac abnormality is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During pregnancy, the cardiac output increases by 30-50% due to increased plasma volume and heart rate, beginning as early as the second month and peaking around 30 weeks of gestation.
  • Simultaneously, there is a significant reduction in systemic vascular resistance due to the vasodilatory effects of progesterone and other factors.
  • In aortic regurgitation (AR), the regurgitant volume depends on systemic vascular resistance.
  • As vascular resistance drops during pregnancy, less blood flows back into the left ventricle, resulting in reduced murmur intensity.
  • This same mechanism applies to mitral regurgitation (MR) and mitral valve prolapse (MVP), where murmurs may remain unchanged or even become softer during pregnancy.

Explanation of other options:

Aortic stenosis (Option A): The murmur of AS becomes louder during pregnancy due to increased stroke volume and cardiac output across a fixed, narrowed valve.

Mitral stenosis (Option C): This murmur also becomes more prominent during pregnancy and is associated with a risk of pulmonary edema, especially during labor or fluid overload.

Coarctation of aorta (Option D): This condition also worsens due to increased cardiac output and can lead to hypertensive complications. The murmur may increase in intensity due to elevated flow across the narrowed segment.

Key Takeaways:

  • Regurgitant murmurs (AR, MR) may decrease in intensity during pregnancy due to reduced peripheral vascular resistance.
  • Stenotic lesions (AS, MS) tend to worsen during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output.
  • Cardiovascular adaptation in pregnancy can alter the presentation of pre-existing heart conditions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is admitted with a stroke after a prolonged pyrexial illness. On examination, she is in sinus rhythm, has splenomegaly, and a pansystolic murmur at the apex. Blood cultures confirm infective endocarditis. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Streptococcus viridans is the most common cause of native valve infective endocarditis, particularly in subacute presentations. These organisms are commensals of the oral cavity and upper respiratory tract. Minor mucosal trauma (e.g., chewing, brushing, dental procedures) can cause transient bacteremia leading to infection of previously damaged or abnormal valves.

The clinical presentation in this case (prolonged low-grade fever, embolic event (stroke), splenomegaly, and a murmur) is classical of subacute native valve endocarditis, consistent with S. viridans etiology.

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B):

Common in acute endocarditis, particularly among IV drug users, or patients with catheters/skin infections. Tends to involve normal valves and often leads to rapid destruction. It typically causes right-sided (tricuspid) IE in IV drug use.

Streptococcus bovis (Option C):

Less common. Associated with colonic neoplasia and liver disease. Its presence mandates colonoscopy to rule out colon cancer. Penicillin G is the treatment of choice for S. bovis endocarditis, typically given for 4 weeks.

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option D):

A coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CONS), which is a major cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially post-surgical, as it is a skin commensal and opportunistic pathogen introduced during procedures.

Key Takeaway:

  • M/c cause for native valve endocarditis: Streptococcus viridans > Staph aureus > Enterococcus
  • M/c cause for prosthetic valve endocarditis:
    • Coagulase negative Staph aureus > Staph aureus (Early, < 1 year)
    • Streptococcus viridans (Late, > 1 year)
  • Infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers: Staph aureus (right-sided endocarditis)

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac lesions confers the lowest risk for developing infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The risk of developing infective endocarditis (IE) varies depending on the underlying structural cardiac lesion.

  • Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a low-flow, non-turbulent lesion that does not involve high-pressure jets or abnormal endocardial surfaces; hence, it has the lowest risk for IE.
  • Even among congenital heart diseases, ASD (especially ostium secundum type) is considered low risk, whereas lesions like VSD or PDA confer a higher risk due to turbulent flow.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and exertional dyspnea. Her history includes prosthetic mitral valve replacement 2.5 years ago. On examination, she has petechial hemorrhages in the nails. Echocardiography confirms moderate paravalvular mitral regurgitation. Infective endocarditis is suspected and confirmed with positive blood cultures. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents >1 year after prosthetic valve replacement, placing her in the category of late prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE). The microbial spectrum of late PVE is similar to native valve endocarditis, with Streptococcus viridans being the most common pathogen, responsible for approximately 40% of all cases.

Other organisms include:

  • Staphylococcus species (~25%)
  • Enterococcus (~10%), especially in elderly patients

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis:

  • Early PVE (<1 year): Commonly due to coagulase-negative Staphylococci, particularly epidermidis
  • Late PVE (>1 year): Mimics native valve endocarditis - Streptococcus viridans > aureus > Enterococci
  • Clinical features: Fever, new murmur, embolic phenomena, positive cultures
  • Paravalvular leak on echo is suggestive of prosthetic valve endocarditis

Explanation of other options:

Coxiella burnetii (Option A): A rare cause, associated with culture-negative endocarditis, often in chronic Q fever or immunocompromised individuals. Less likely here due to positive cultures.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): More often causes acute native valve endocarditis, especially in IV drug users or patients with catheters. Less likely here due to subacute course and timeline.

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option C): A frequent cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis, usually within the first 12 months post-replacement. Not the typical pathogen after >1 year.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is admitted to the intensive therapy unit with left ventricular failure following a recent myocardial infarction. Despite early intervention with angioplasty performed within minutes of symptom onset, his systolic BP is 80 mmHg and pulse rate is 105/min. An intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) is inserted and timed to inflate at the dicrotic notch. What does the dicrotic notch represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dicrotic notch is a characteristic dip seen on the descending limb of the arterial pressure waveform, which corresponds to closure of the aortic valve. This marks the end of systole and the beginning of diastole.

In the context of intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) therapy, used in conditions like cardiogenic shock or severe left ventricular failure, precise timing of balloon inflation and deflation is critical:

  • The balloon deflates just before systole, which reduces afterload, thereby lowering myocardial oxygen demand and increasing stroke volume.
  • It inflates at the dicrotic notch (i.e., immediately after aortic valve closure) to augment diastolic pressure, thereby enhancing coronary artery perfusion, which is especially important during myocardial ischemia.

Thus, proper synchronization with the dicrotic notch is essential to maximize both hemodynamic support and myocardial oxygen supply-demand balance.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aortic valve opening (Option A): Occurs at the start of systole; represented by the upstroke of the pressure waveform, not the dicrotic notch.

Mitral valve opening (Option C): Occurs after aortic valve closure, but it's not seen on the arterial waveform and does not correspond with the dicrotic notch.

Mitral valve closure (Option D): Occurs at the start of systole, just before aortic valve opens, unrelated to the dicrotic notch.

Key Takeaway:

  • Dicrotic notch = Aortic valve closure
  • IABP inflates at the dicrotic notch (start of diastole)
  • IABP deflates just before systole to reduce afterload

questions.text: Which of the following provides a reliable clue to the severity of mitral stenosis during clinical examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In mitral stenosis (MS), the hallmark auscultatory feature is a mid-diastolic murmur (MDM) best heard at the apex in left lateral decubitus position.

  • A longer murmur duration reflects a greater diastolic pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle, indicating more severe stenosis.
  • Another related clinical clue is the interval between S2 and the opening snap (OS):
    • A shorter S2-OS interval suggests higher left atrial pressure, and thus more severe MS.

The mitral valve area <1.0 cm2 is indicative of severe MS (normal mitral valve area is 4-6 cm2)

Explanation of Other Options:

Intensity of MDM (Option A): Variable and influenced by factors like flow volume (e.g., anemia, fever). Does not reliably indicate severity.

Loud S1 (Option B): Associated with mobile valve leaflets. Can be absent in severe, calcified MS. Not a severity indicator.

Presence of opening snap (Option C): Indicates a pliable valve and supports MS diagnosis, but doesn't reflect degree of stenosis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with increasing shortness of breath over the past few years and now reports a transient ischemic attack (TIA) with left-sided weakness and incoordination that resolved within 24 hours. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and he is in sinus rhythm. Auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur that changes in character with posture, but no opening snap is noted. Biochemical investigations are unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has suffered a TIA, most likely due to embolism from an intra-cardiac cause. Mitral stenosis with Atrial fibrillation is a possibility, but there was no clinical evidence for the same, and the patient was in sinus rhythm.

The presence of embolic phenomenon and the characteristic change of murmur at apex changing with posture suggests 'tumor plop' due to left atrial myxoma.

Left atrial myxoma:

  • Myxomas are the most common intracardiac tumors
  • Myxoma can occur in any cardiac chamber, but occurs most commonly in the left atrium attached to the interatrial septum.
  • It is a gelatinous, friable tumour, which leads to transient signs of mitral stenosis that only occur if the tumour approaches the mitral valve orifice.
  • There may be an early diastolic "tumor plop" as the tumour prolapses through the mitral valve.
  • Patient may present with embolic phenomenon, features of heart failure or constitutional features like fever, weight loss etc.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aortic regurgitation (Option A): Typically presents with a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border, but not usually posture-dependent. Also associated with widened pulse pressure, which is not noted here.

Mitral stenosis (Option B): Would present with diastolic murmur + opening snap and signs of left atrial enlargement. Embolic events are possible due to atrial fibrillation, but this patient is in sinus rhythm and lacks an opening snap.

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (Option D): Causes a systolic murmur, not diastolic. Also associated with syncope, dyspnea, or sudden death, not typically with TIA or posture-dependent murmurs.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female developed rheumatic fever with carditis, but was found to have no significant residual cardiac lesions on follow-up. According to current guidelines, this patient should receive secondary prophylaxis for rheumatic fever until what age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines for secondary prophylaxis in rheumatic fever:

  • Patients with rheumatic fever and carditis but no residual valvular disease should receive prophylaxis for 10 years after the last episode or until age 21, whichever is longer.
  • In this case, the patient had her last episode at age 15, so 10 years of prophylaxis would extend until age 25.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency room in a collapsed state after sustaining a precordial stab wound. Which of the following cardiac valves is most likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The tricuspid valve is the most anterior of the four cardiac valves. Due to its location just beneath the sternum, it is the most commonly injured valve in penetrating chest trauma, especially precordial stab wounds.

  • In such injuries, the right ventricle is the most frequently affected chamber, followed closely by valvular structures like the tricuspid valve.
  • Penetrating cardiac injuries can lead to life-threatening complications such as:
    • Hemorrhagic shock
    • Cardiac tamponade (Beck's triad: hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins)
    • Valvular insufficiency
    • Intracardiac shunts
    • Infective pericarditis as a late complication
  • In patients who survive the initial injury, valvular trauma (especially to the tricuspid valve) may present later with signs of right-sided heart failure, such as peripheral edema and hepatic congestion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aortic valve (Option A): Located posteriorly. Hence, rarely injured in anterior penetrating trauma.

Pulmonary valve (Option C): Though located superiorly, it is less anterior than the tricuspid valve.

Mitral valve (Option D): Lies posteriorly, between the left atrium and ventricle, and is protected from direct anterior trauma.

choices.text: Mitral stenosis with a calcified valve

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic. On cardiac auscultation, she is noted to have a loud first heart sound (S1), an early diastolic sound, followed by a mid-diastolic murmur. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of loud S1, early diastolic sound (opening snap), and mid-diastolic murmur is characteristic of mitral stenosis with mobile, non-calcified valve leaflets, often seen in young patients with rheumatic heart disease.

  • Loud S1 occurs due to forceful closure of pliable mitral leaflets. When the leaflets are still mobile, they remain wide open until the end of diastole and then close abruptly, producing a loud sound.
  • The opening snap (OS) is an early diastolic sound caused by the sudden tensing of the valve apparatus as it opens under elevated left atrial pressure. This can only happen if the valve is flexible and not calcified.
  • The mid-diastolic murmur results from turbulent flow across the stenotic mitral valve, best heard at the apex with the bell of the stethoscope in the left lateral position.

Note: These findings not only confirm the diagnosis but also have therapeutic implications. A loud S1 and clear OS suggest a favorable valve morphology, making the patient a good candidate for percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy (PBMV).

Explanation of other options:

Mitral stenosis with a calcified valve (Option A): Calcified valves lose their pliability. As a result, S1 becomes soft, and the opening snap is absent or delayed due to reduced mobility. These patients are less suitable for PBMV and may require surgical valve replacement.

Mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation (Option B): AF leads to irregularly irregular rhythm and variable S1 intensity, making the auscultatory findings less consistent. A classic loud S1 and opening snap are typically not heard in persistent AF.

Mitral stenosis with pulmonary hypertension (Option D): Pulmonary hypertension produces a loud pulmonary component of the second heart sound (P2) but does not affect the mitral S1 or cause an opening snap. It often occurs in advanced mitral stenosis but is not characterized by the auscultatory findings in this case.

choices.text: Diastolic murmur in left sternal border

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic finding of Tricuspid regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prominent V waves in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) is a classic clinical finding in TR.

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR):

TR is the backflow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole, due to incompetence of the tricuspid valve.

Etiology:

  • Primary TR (Structural valve abnormalities): Ebstein anomaly, Carcinoid syndrome, Marfan syndrome
  • Secondary TR (~90%): Due to pulmonary hypertension or left-sided valvular heart disease

Auscultation Findings:

  • Murmur:
    • Pansystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border (LLSB)
    • Increases on inspiration → Carvallo's sign (important to differentiate from MR)
  • Heart Sounds:
    • Normal or soft S1
    • S2 may not show significant changes (not typically associated with wide split S2)

JVP Findings:

  • Prominent V waves (due to systolic regurgitant flow into RA) → Also called c-v waves or Lancisi sign

Other Clinical Signs:

  • Pulsatile hepatomegaly
  • Signs of right-sided heart failure: Ascites, Peripheral edema, Hepatojugular reflux

Explanation of other options:

Diastolic murmur in left sternal border (Option A): This is characteristic of aortic regurgitation (early diastolic murmur) or tricuspid stenosis, not TR. TR causes a systolic, not diastolic, murmur.

Pansystolic murmur at apex (Option B): This is seen in mitral regurgitation, not TR. TR also causes a pansystolic murmur, but it is best heard at the left lower sternal border, not the apex.

Widely split S2 (Option C): Occurs in right bundle branch block, ASD, or pulmonary stenosis, not specific to TR. It's due to delayed right ventricular systole and is not a diagnostic clue for TR.

choices.text: Artifact due to lack of simultaneous recording

questions.text: A 24-year-old man's blood pressure is consistently 30 mmHg higher in the right arm compared to the left arm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A significant blood pressure difference between arms, with higher pressure in the right arm, strongly suggests supravalvular aortic stenosis.

In supravalvular aortic stenosis, the narrowing is located just above the aortic valve, at the ascending aorta, frequently affecting the origin of major arch branches, particularly the brachiocephalic (innominate) artery.

This anatomical distortion results in the systolic jet being preferentially directed into the brachiocephalic artery, which supplies the right arm, leading to higher systolic pressures in the right arm compared to the left.

Other findings may include:

  • Unequal carotid pulsations (right > left)
  • Murmur of aortic stenosis (ejection systolic, best heard at right upper sternal border)
  • Often associated with William's syndrome (elfin facies, hypercalcemia, cognitive deficits)

This presentation distinguishes it from coarctation of the aorta, which usually causes lower limb BP disparity rather than upper limb differences.

Explanation of other options:

Arterial obstructive disease (Option A): Usually causes lower pressure in the affected limb, which would typically be unilateral and associated with absent or diminished pulses, not consistently elevated right arm pressure.

Artifact due to lack of simultaneous recording (Option B): While non-simultaneous measurements may cause minor variations in readings, a consistent 30 mmHg difference is unlikely to be due to artifact and suggests an organic vascular cause.

Subclavian steal syndrome (Option C): This involves reversed vertebral artery flow due to proximal subclavian artery stenosis (usually left-sided). It can lead to dizziness, syncope, and a lower BP in the affected arm, but it is more common in older individuals with atherosclerosis

questions.text: Which if the following is not a documented cause of Mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Marfan syndrome is not associated with mitral stenosis. Instead, it commonly causes:

  • Mitral valve prolapse (MVP)
  • Aortic root dilatation
  • Aortic regurgitation

Causes of Mitral Stenosis:

  • Rheumatic fever (>90% of cases): M/C cause (Option A ruled out)
  • Congenital abnormalities (e.g., parachute mitral valve, double orifice mitral valve, supravalvular mitral ring)
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (Option B ruled out)
  • Radiation-induced valvular damage
  • Age-related calcium deposition
  • Chronic sequelae of infective endocarditis
  • Certain drugs (e.g., ergot derivatives, bromocriptine)
  • Mucopolysaccharidoses (e.g., Hurler syndrome): Can cause valvular thickening and dysfunction (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 24-year-old student is evaluated for a murmur. On examination, a harsh systolic murmur is heard over the precordium, which does not change with inspiration. ECG shows features of biventricular hypertrophy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is a congenital defect involving an opening in the interventricular septum, allowing left-to-right shunting of blood.

  • Murmur: Harsh pansystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border, typically unchanged with inspiration (suggesting it is not right-sided).
  • ECG findings: The left ventricle hypertrophies due to volume overload, while the right ventricle hypertrophies due to pressure overload from the shunted blood; hence, biventricular hypertrophy.
  • Right-sided murmurs (like in tricuspid regurgitation) typically increase with inspiration (Carvallo's sign), which is absent here, ruling out a right-sided lesion.

This combination of harsh systolic murmur and biventricular hypertrophy strongly points to a VSD.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aortic stenosis (Option A): Leads to left ventricular hypertrophy, not biventricular. The murmur is ejection systolic, heard best at right upper sternal border (aortic area), and may radiate to carotids.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Option B): Also causes left ventricular hypertrophy, not biventricular. Murmur is systolic, increases with Valsalva, and is often associated with dynamic obstruction.

Mitral regurgitation (Option C): Leads to left atrial and left ventricular dilation, not biventricular hypertrophy. Murmur is holosystolic, best heard at apex, often radiating to axilla.

questions.text: A 52-year-old obese woman was noticed to have a systolic murmur over her precordium. The murmur becomes more intense during isometric handgrip exercise. What is the most likely cause of her murmur?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Increased murmur intensity with handgrip suggests a regurgitant lesion, and the most likely cause is mitral regurgitation.

Isometric handgrip increases afterload (i.e., systemic vascular resistance). This helps differentiate the type of murmur based on how intensity changes:

  • Increases in murmur intensity: MR, AR, VSD

These are regurgitant lesions, and increased afterload augments the backflow, intensifying the murmur.

  • Decreases in murmur intensity: AS, MVP, HOCM (Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy)

These are outflow or obstruction-related lesions and are reduced by increased afterload. (Options A, B & D ruled out)

choices.text: His family members should be checked for a similar condition
He should start treatment with a cholesterol-lowering drug
He should undergo further tests to check for any autoimmune disorder
He may require heart surgery at a later date

questions.text: A 42-year-old healthy man is found to have a faint systolic murmur during a routine health check. Echocardiography reveals a bicuspid aortic valve. What is the most appropriate advice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) is the most common congenital cardiac malformation, affecting about 1-2% of the population.
  • Though many individuals remain asymptomatic early in life, progressive valve dysfunction (especially AS or AR) can occur over time due to accelerated fibrosis and calcification.
  • By the fifth or sixth decade, up to 30-50% may require aortic valve replacement or surgery for associated aortopathy (e.g., ascending aortic aneurysm).
  • Therefore, patients with BAV should be counseled about the potential need for surgery in the future and monitored regularly with echocardiography.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option A: Although BAV can have a familial component (incidence ~9%), it is not routinely recommended to screen all family members unless there's a strong family history of valve disease or aortopathy.

Option B: BAV is a structural congenital abnormality, not related to lipid metabolism. Statins do not prevent valve calcification or degeneration in BAV.

Option C: There is no association between BAV and autoimmune disorders. Autoimmune testing is irrelevant in an otherwise healthy person with an isolated congenital valve defect.

questions.text: The use of prostaglandin to keep the ductus arteriosus open is necessary in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tricuspid atresia is a form of ductus-dependent congenital heart disease. In this condition, the tricuspid valve is absent, preventing blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle. To maintain adequate pulmonary circulation, the neonate relies on:

  • Right-to-left atrial shunt (via atrial septal defect)
  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) to deliver blood from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries

In such ductus-dependent lesions, PGE1 infusion is life-saving to maintain ductal patency until definitive surgical intervention is possible.

Ductus-dependent congenital heart disease (requiring a patent ductus for maintaining pulmonary/ systemic circulation):

  • Tricuspid atresia
  • Transposition of great arteries
  • Tetralogy of Fallot (severe)
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
  • Critical pulmonary or aortic stenosis

Explanation of Other Options:

Atrioventricular septal defect (Option B): This defect, often associated with Down syndrome, typically presents with left-to-right shunting. It is not duct-dependent, as pulmonary blood flow is usually sufficient through the septal defects.

Gerbode defect (Option C): A rare defect involving a left ventricle to right atrium shunt, which may be congenital or acquired (e.g., post-infective endocarditis). It is not duct-dependent and usually presents with features of volume overload.

Ventricular septal defect (Option D): VSDs are usually acyanotic lesions with left-to-right shunt. Although large VSDs may cause heart failure, they are not ductus-dependent for survival in the neonatal period.

choices.text: Reverse the anticoagulation with vitamin K
Stop warfarin and start intravenous heparin
Continue warfarin and add intravenous heparin

questions.text: A patient with an aortic valve replacement presents with right hemiparesis. A CT scan confirms a cerebral infarction with no evidence of hemorrhage. The INR is 2.0. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patients with mechanical heart valves require lifelong anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolism. However, in the setting of an acute ischemic stroke, continued use of warfarin during the acute phase may increase the risk of hemorrhagic transformation of the infarct.

The preferred strategy is:

  • To stop warfarin
  • To start intravenous unfractionated heparin, which has a shorter half-life and can be rapidly adjusted or discontinued if bleeding complications arise.

Explanation of Other Options:

Reverse the anticoagulation with vitamin K (Option A): This would be appropriate if the patient had intracerebral hemorrhage or over-anticoagulation, but here there is no bleeding, and the patient requires continued anticoagulation due to the mechanical valve.

Increase the dose of warfarin (Option C): Although an INR of 2.0 may be subtherapeutic for a mechanical aortic valve (target usually 2.5-3.5), increasing warfarin immediately after stroke increases the risk of hemorrhagic conversion.

Continue warfarin and add intravenous heparin (Option D): This increases bleeding risk unnecessarily. Bridging with heparin alone is safer in the acute setting.

questions.text: Severe aortic stenosis is characterized by an aortic valve area less than:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Severe aortic stenosis is defined by an aortic valve area <1 cm2, with transaortic velocity >4 m/s and mean pressure gradient >40 mmHg, also indicating severity.
